text: We have switched to homeschooling after our experience with HES, HIS, and HMS.

name: Heather Mckee
text: My children have attended daycare here for the past two years and now my daughter attends their preschool program. Each staff member has loved and treated them like family from the very beginning. Since changing jobs last year, I've added over an hour commute to my daily drive just to keep my children enrolled at Kiddie Care Learning Center. There isn't a daycare in the Wiregrass that could take Kiddie Care's place. If your children aren't enrolled here get them enrolled. If there's a waitlist secure a spot. Coming from a single mother of four, you won't regret it!

name: Angie West-Mendez
text: I absolutely love Kiddie Care Learning Center. I never sent my oldest two children to daycare, so I was worried when I had to find a place for my third child. From day one, I fell in love with Kiddie Care. The staff has taken care of my daughter since she was six-weeks old and I have never had an issue. They are very caring and it shows since my daughter loves being there. I cannot recommend them enough.

name: Fran Ramsey
text: I love this school! My kids have been going here since they were infants, and they are now 8 and 4! My kids feel safe, the teachers are great and they’re learning is phenomenal!

name: Trai-Vana Griffin
text:
Kiddie Care Learning Center is one of the best childcare facilities that I have worked at.

As a parent I know my children are safe, it was tough in the beginning because they have only stayed with my mom but now they love it and they come home everyday talking about their teachers, friends, and what all they have learned in class. You will not go wrong choosing Kiddie Care for your child(ren).

name: Allie Lam
text: I just recently moved my child to a different daycare after being at this one for 9 months. And honestly it was the best thing for me to do and should have done sooner. I really did enjoy him going to Kiddie Care in the beginning. A couple of months into him going was when the problems started. Teachers were not consistent in the class rooms. It seemed like there was a new teacher in the class room every few weeks. The classrooms are over-crowded with kids. I had problems with a couple of his teachers. One of them told him that he could lay in his urine after he told her that he had wet himself at nap time. I told the co-director and she did write the teacher up and moved my child to a different class. And recently I learned that at times when kids are eating, if they talk, their food gets taken away. There is also a write up system which I think is ridiculous. Most of the write ups were things normal 3 year old boys do. Even his teacher said he’s just being a boy on most of them, yet they write them up anyways. His most recent teacher always seemed to have a bad attitude in the mornings and wasn’t a cheery person whatsoever. The co-director tried helping me with some issues I was having but in the end it just wasn’t enough. My child was not happy going to daycare anymore. He started his new daycare on Monday and I can already tell a difference in him. He’s so much happier when he gets home. I’m giving it 2 stars because the co-director was nice and there were a couple of teachers I did appreciate. I would not recommend this daycare to anyone.

name: Amber Mcclendon
text: I highly recommend Kiddie Care Learning Center the staff there is very loving and caring I know they have taken care of my baby like he's their own the staff is amazing

text: This is a wonderful place.  My daughter loves going here she loves all of the teachers.  She gets so excited to as soon as she sees the center.  Everyone is very kind and loving.

text: My daughter went to this center and they are wonderful. She attended the PreK program and when she did her kindergarten testing she scored 103 out of 105! It's an excellent place for your children to gain knowledge!

text: The staff was generally nice and handled my kids very well but I cannot say the same for how situations are handled there. In short we had issues with everything from bullying to letting children listen to news in the van about rape or murder or listen to rap with language that isn't fit for me let alone my kids. Read your contract carefully. I wouldn't say i hated it or really disliked it but i can tell you I wouldn't recommend it. Loved Ms. Rochelle there tho. If she had her own place I would gladly take my kids to her anytime.

text: Kiddie Care has been a consistent source of education, love & patience for almost 2 years.  Our grandson, who lives with us, is now in the new Pre-K program inside the daycare & he's thriving!  There is very little turnover at this facility.  The Director and her staff are excellent listeners, patient with children that may not be "cookie-cutter kids,' and are truly loving and caring toward every age of child.  I have & will continue to recommend KCLC as the BEST place we've found for the things that matter.

name: Patricia Thompson
text: Been to 9 different schools. 2 have been in Saks (Elementary and High). Both are definitely the worst ever. School environment was safe enough, but not a whole lot of learning to be had. Lot of bad teachers, poorly educated students, emphasis on athletics over academics, and basically great if you're an athlete or a student from a privileged family. Everyone else is training for the fast food economy or dropping out. My family went from honor roll in Germany to dropouts in Saks due to the distracting nature (a lot of focus on things that don't matter like racial profiling, football, and sneaking in school prayer, while letting things like crime, bullying, and sexual activity and the needs of the many underprivileged kids fly under the radar), and poor quality of the school (look up the poor math and reading scores as evidence). I left this school for one in Georgia and there was an instant turnaround! Just by getting out of that environment, I quickly graduated with honors. I can go into much more detail, but I'll leave it here. This review is based on my own recollection of experiences during 1998-2001 and is honest to the best of my ability. I gave 2 stars because of a couple of excellent teachers and a decent amount of safety on campus.

name: Jason Bradwell
text: My partner and I decided to go here after the new year started and we were both pleased with the experience. Both of us have such fond memories of the center from when we were kids in the 1980s on school field trips. The center is still as fascinating and tranquil as it was then. My favorite exhibit was definitely the aviary. It was the first time I ever saw a bald eagle up close. The lake and the carnivorous plant bog were so idyllic and eye catching; we didn't want to leave. It was like something out of a nature painting. The classroom was also a highlight with live reptiles. We are going to adopt an animal and will definitely be returning here often to donate and be with nature. It is almost like a gasp of fresh air in the midst of a chaotic city. We are both eagerly anticipating the bi-annual "Skywatch" event.

Among them are beautiful, sweet faces whose goodness radiates from sweet souls.  .  .  .a little bit of heaven on Earth.

resp.text: Thanks so much for your sweet words, Claudia. We strive daily to be a "home" for our students, because we feel that when their basic needs are met (especially feeling "at home"), they feel prepared/eager to show that same care and concern to others--thereby reflecting Light and Truth in the world. :)

name: Brittany Johnson
text: I've gone here for two years now. It has become my home away from home, and I hate having to be away for summers! Yes, it has it's flaws, and it isn't right for everyone, but Judson is the place where young women can go in and become life longer learners. We also don't usually meet our husbands here, but we do get to meet our bridesmaids :) Hope this helped out someone!

They not only need to allow these girls to go to prom, but they need to fire the idiots who punished these girls because this is America in the 21st century, not some Russian school where freedom to love who you love, is legally struck from the laws of the land. We have those freedoms in this country, and if they try to cry "religious freedom" they need to remember that this, is in fact, a PUBLIC school. And PUBLIC SCHOOLS MUST ADHERE TO THE LAW, THE LAW OF SEPARATION OF CHURCH AND STATE. Wanna be sued? Well EXPECT IT! The ACLU, GLAAD, LAMBDA LEGAL, HRC, and the GSA, will all be suing your district on the grounds of violating the laws broken. Enjoy your school system being damn near bankrupt, and your ass-backward city of bumpkin ideology getting exposed for the ignorance on display. Because here in the good 'ol 21st century, us MODERN folk, don't put up with bigots too well.

name: Evan Gries
text:
Copy/paste of some recent events.

I have recently learned that my high school, Alexandria High School, decided to act out of hatred and intolerance and (under my impression) punish two young female students for trying to attend prom together. After roughly an hour of frantically searching for more information, I have contacted various organizations throughout Alabama to help resolve this issue. Below is the email that I have just sent to the Superintendent of the Calhoun County Schools.

*I share this with my Facebook feed to remind us of the work we have to still be done to guarantee equal protection under the law, and I also hope this story gains attention and picks up traction from this post.*

*EDIT: There has been no mention of prom proceedings from the administration, but the students involved have received in-school suspension.
__________________________
Good afternoon Mr. Dyar,

My name is Nick Wyville, and you may remember me as a graduate of Alexandria High School in Alexandria, AL. I am currently a sophomore at Harvard College. I hope all is well with you.

Today I was informed of a situation that took place at my high school, Alexandria High School. Our school was hosting its annual talent show, and after a girl sang a song, her girlfriend asked her to prom while on the stage. Under my impression, the students have been suspended until further notice, as have the hosts of the talent show. I have also been told that the couple will not be allowed to go to prom. According to a friend, the principal came over the intercom and apologized to anyone that was “offended” by this display, and said it did not represent the school’s “values." A few years ago, this same school was under fire for its religious practices.

Today I write to you to urge the principal of Alexandria High School to drop all charges against the two young girls and to the hosts of the talent show, and any others involved. Federal law and the United State Constitution bars the harassment of LGBT students in public high school. If the case is made that this was a public display of affection in front of an audience, then there is precedent that contradicts that very action. When the talent show first unveiled itself, a male proposed to a female, and they faced no consequences. I, along with many others, can stand witness to that.

The students must also be allowed to attend prom together. The 1st Amendment of the Constitution of the United States guaranteed their desire to attend, and the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment protects their rights to enjoy equal treatment by school faculty and staff. If you would like more information on that, I recommend reading the court notes on Fricke v. Lynch here.

I have contacted members of the Alabama Human Rights Campaign, the Alabama ACLU, and multiple media outlets, both national and local. If these unjust charges are not dropped against these students, further action will be taken.

This is a clear violation of the law and it tramples the two young girls’ moral character. I hope you can resolve this incident. If I can be of further help, please let me know.

Best,

Nick Wyville

name: Steve Brown
text:
Amridge University has been a nightmare to deal with. They lied right off the bat with stating that Biblical languages were not required for this specific degree. After signing up they never established a link with Canvas until the second day of the starting semester. upon watching the first part of the very first lecture, I realized that they had misrepresented themselves and asked to be removed from their roster. They have since sent a bill totaling just under $4,000. for a class that was never started. Ask yourself is this Christian activity, it appears like their god is mammon. The class did not actually start until the second of the month, I did not have access until the second day of the class. Save yourself a lot of hassle and look elsewhere for a true Christian experience and education.

Update, Amridge University did finally do what was right after I submitted a form for review and retract the fees for that semester, for which I am greatful.

people in the school rather than not eating. His math score has went up. This school staff will as a hole help with anything a student needs to have and be at their very best in and out of school. He is in the ninth grade he likes this school over all and wants to continue going to school here until he graduates. They have a great school counselor. She works hard with my grandson to help him with any questions he has concerning anything. The school nurse is really nice and works with him knowing what his needs are and specific needs and concerns we discuss. Students with specific needs will benefit going to school here. My grandson is doing good and this is a big family destressor.

name: Alan Broom
text: Growing up “local” we all knew of Lyman Ward Military Academy. Our girlfriends swooned over the sharply uniformed cadets at the theater on Friday nights. Best to go on Saturday night! Or perhaps it was our parents telling us they were looking into it! All of my “local” buddies will understand that. Well friends, I finally made it. My dad would be so proud! Everyday I go to the beautiful campus of The Southern Preparatory Academy. It’s not at all the place I pictured when dad threatened. As a man, it is a place I wish I had experienced in my youth. As a father, it is a place I wish my son could have experienced. The keys to success exist in this place; delivered by some of the finest people I’ve ever known. I consider my part of this mission a privilege and I wish EVERY American male had the opportunity to experience Southern Prep.

name: Craig Cochran
text: There is simply no institution anywhere that cares as much about the development of young men as Southern Preparatory Academy. The staff are 110% dedicated to the success of the cadets. I can confidently say that Southern Prep changed my son's life, and he will never forget the valuable lessons he has learned.

name: Brandi Cherry
text: Such a great, positive environment for young men! I can't say enough about the staff at Southern Prep. They genuinely love these boys and want the best for them! I continue to see great things happening on campus... i know these things wouldn't be possible without the leadership and staff at Southern Prep. Their dedication to Southern Prep and these young men doesn't go unnoticed.

name: Mitchell Hicks
text:
I went to LWMA in the same years that two gentleman who have left bad comments about hazing and other stuff like fighting. I was small and not that tough when I got there but absolutely nothing happened to me like that. I learned so much about life and how to be a person that people would look up to and how to be a leader and live life responsibly. I was there with Col. Bill Jenertte who, even after I Graduated stayed in contact and anytime I was in a fork in the road after I graduated I could call him and if he didn’t answer he would call me back or if he was busy another staff member would call me back and they all remember their students. They saved my life. I graduated as the Battalion Commander and I started there like everyone else, a scrub. I went through leadership trading and left at the top of the ranks. I loved that place so much some weekends when we had the opportunity to go home for open weekend I would choose to stay on campus. And I’m from Destin Florida where it’s warm and I could go on my dads boat and jet skis and have a great weekend but LWMA became a family to me too that some weekends I would want to stay there. If I could say one thing with 100% certainty is that if I never attended LWMA I honestly know I wouldn’t of been able to have the life I have now and I sure wouldn’t know how to live life with character. I live by a cadet code. That is
To be faithful, honest, and sincere in every act and purpose and to know honorable failure is better than success by unfairness or cheating.

That cadet code has made it possible to now own a house and own two charter boats and I also have a 500 Ton captains license. I have a baby on the way and I was just telling my wife that I would love to drive up there this year to visit the campus.

Long story short: Every teenager should go because it would save their lives and the education they would get with the sports and the more one on one with teachers can not compare to any other school in America. I am forever greatful to LWMA. And bad reviews left on LWMA is from kids that probably never had the mindset to become a better person

name: Jill Jones
text: Southern Prep is an all-male military boarding academy serving grades 6 through 12.  If your son needs more structure and self-discipline, this is the school you are looking for.  While they offer sports, technical training, aviation, and a college-prep curriculum, it is the expectation of excellence, accountability, and self-reliance that sets Southern Prep apart from other schools.  If your son is going through the mine field of adolescence and you feel he is not living up to his potential, let him attend Southern Prep. Get him away from those unnecessary distractions and go to a place where boys learn what it takes to succeed in life and become successful young men, whether that be in college, the military, or a career. The life skills they learn at Southern Prep Academy will serve them their whole life.

name: Morgan C
text: I have worked at Southern Prep for a little over 6 months, but it only took me a few days to realize how special this academy is. I have seen many boys transform and discover their potential while forming bonds that will last a lifetime. I definitely recommend sending your son to Southern Prep!

name: Kimberly Wicker
text: I have worked in the education field for 15 years and this will be my 3rd year at Southern Prep. I feel beyond blessed to have this opportunity to work in a place that goes above and beyond for each one of the boys that steps onto this campus. This is an amazing school that offers so many opportunities for young men to become our future leaders.

name: Bobby Alaimo
text:
Lyman ward Military Academy saved my life...

I was born in Brooklyn New York and raised in Miami during the 80s and 90s.

Lyman ward guided me into becoming the man I am today, a Combat Veteran with a distinguished record, and a proud father of two beautiful children.

I give special thanks to Col. Jenrette and 1st Sgt Frank for believing in me from day one.

Go Rangers
Class of 1994

name: Cole Boston
text: I attended Lyman Ward my Junior year and for the following Summer School Program. My experience at the Academy was life changing! Not only did their rigorous classes and committed teachers help me realize my academic potential, the staff in the Military Department taught me the virtues of leadership and instilled within me a moral code to keep myself on the right path! During my time at the Academy I played football, basketball, and soccer. Our team even went to the State Championship! I also was a member of the elite Sword Drill team. (Video of Sword Drill performance on their website! Check it out!) Some of my bests friends that I have today I met at the Academy, but sadly I see other classmates of mine posting troubling reviews that are untrue as I was in attendance at the Academy when they were. These individuals never took hold of the great opportunity that they were given at the Academy and were consistent trouble makers that refused to use their great potential for good. I highly recommend Lyman Ward Military Academy to youth that want to step past their traditional peers and set themselves on the path to excellence, and for parents who want such for their children!

text: My son went from being a lost boy into a fine young man under the care of Lyman Ward. He attended Lyman Ward for six years and through their support and guidance he is now enrolled in a University and has even made the President's list (top 5 in the school). I know it may not fit every student but those students needing structure and discipline, Lyman Ward made a positive difference in my son.

I went through hell at times, being challenged mentally and physically until I was at my breaking point. While I wouldn't want to go through it again I am grateful I went through it. I wouldn't be the person I am today if I hadn't attended. I truly appreciate ALL faculty, staff, and cadets that made this life changing experience for me.

text: Learned so much from this Academy. I'm a former Cadet/Student and loved this school and it's Campus! Learned Discipline traits and Life Skills that I use even in my life as a Student at The University of North Carolina @Charlotte.Graduated with Honors from Junior College and I attribute my 3.65 GPA to Southern Prep Academy. I learned Study Discipline and had the best teachers who were great in teaching. The love I received from this Academy and the Discipline will always be with me and I cherish my experience @Southern Preparatory Academy. U will read some of these reviews from former Cadets who turned out to be Sour Apples but im one of the Former Cadets that LOVED Southern Preparatory Academy and am Taking what I learned there to my advantage.I just graduated with Honors from Junior College and am a 2 time Army Achievement Medal Awardee in the The U.S. Army. I will always look back on this school as the School that shaped me into a WINNER:)

name: Jared Norrell
text: My two sons attend Lyman Ward and I could not be happier with the men they are becoming.  Take some time and look closely at the school.  Don't believe all the hype out there on the internet that is being posted by bitter, unsuccessful people.  There are thousands of young men that have passed through the ranks of the Lyman Ward Corps of Cadets and gone on to be extremely successful in almost every walk of life.  Fact of the matter is, most of the people putting negative things out there about the school really don't like themselves.  I know for a fact that one of the gentlemen that posted a negative comment here should have been arrested but instead the administration just kicked him off campus for his own benefit...and yet he is still spiteful.  Is Lyman Ward for everybody?  Absolutely not.  The academy has a great mission and a wonderful staff that truly care about the boys there.  Simply put, Lyman Ward Academy turns boys into respectable men that any parent can be proud of....

name: Nick Myers
text: I attended and graduated from Lyman Ward in 1980.  My brother also attended but withdrew so I can honestly say that LWMA is not for everyone.  The school provides the environment and tools but as well know some teenagers will conform and some are unable to change their ways.  The school isn’t there to raise kids but to grow them, raising children will always be a parents responsibilty.  Again, the school isn’t for everyone but can be a positive influence for those who do stick it out.

name: Wilson Scott
text: I am very proud to say I attended Lyman Ward for 5 years of my teenage life. I give this school full credit for making me the man I am today. There is no telling where I would be now if I had not spent those years there. Thank you LWMA!!!

name: Stanley Chapman
text: I had read many reviews prior to sending my son to this school.  Some reviews were bad and a few were good.  Well, I have decided to share my experience as a parent.  I have been very impressed with the people who help run this school.  I have visited the school and engaged cadets there in open and honest discussion.  I agree, the school can be very difficult for students who are very determined NOT to make an inner change and correct incorrect behavior.  There is a chance that your child may not change, but I feel it is very slim.  Many of the students will tell you that it is not helping them and they have not changed but that is just so that you will bring them back home.  If you stick with it, you will notice a change in behavior regardless of what they will try to tell you.  The school has been very open and honest with me.  Even when the biggest misfortunate event took place this past semester, they kept every parent informed continuously and immediately.  The price is somewhat high, but if you can somehow afford it, even one semester is worth it.  I wish the school was somehow more affordable because there are many young men out here whose lives would be saved and changed for the better.  If you have a troubled teen, you can either do nothing (which can eventually lead to jail or the grave) or you can make an attempt to correct their path and possibly save them.  Sending your kid here does not promise to save your child, but if the worst is eventually going to happen(fate), you would rather look back later and know you did eveything you could have done.  Even though it was a difficult decision to make, I am glad that I sent my son here.  I will more than likely enroll him back into the public school system next semester.  He may not be perfect, but I feel confident that after going to this school this semester, he will not get anywhere close back to the person he was.  If he does, I know the doors of Lyman Ward are still open and the people there will be willing to help.

name: Angela Murray
text: My two sons currently attend LWMA and it has been a life changing experience for both of them. They are thriving academically and athletically and are becoming two incredible young men to be very proud of as adults! This is an amazing institution and serves many young men well now and has done so for several generations. I think as parents we must be careful when looking for educational and "life" opportunities or options for our children that we are careful to dig deep and do research to validate the opinions and statements being posted on the internet or in print. There have certainly been times when my boys weren't "happy" at school, but that's the hard part of being a parent... actually being a parent and not always a friend.

name: Trina Barrett
text: My son went to Lyman Ward. Due to his own issues, he did not complete the program. However, I credit LWMA with saving his life and getting him as far as went. If you have a son who is need of redirection, please consider this school. Disgruntled former students have posted some bad reviews. This is a military school, aligned with the Army Corps of Cadets. They do not go easy on the boys, but "easy" is a sure ticket to a hard life. Many kids have gone through this school and turned everything around. They are productive men, fathers and husbands, who would have had a very different outcome with out LWMA.

name: Steve Trowbridge
text: Great experience there as an adolescent. Got my grades turned around and met a lotta good friends in process.

name: Randy Lee
text: Great school close to where I grew up and currently live in the Alexander City / Lake Martin region.

name: Webb Adams
text:
I've read reviews of Lyman Ward Military Academy, some good, some bad. Most of the good ones come from parents who have seen their sons change and learn discipline and respect and attitude and improvements in their grades. Most of the negative ones have come from the cadets themselves though some of these are also positive. I am an alumus of Lyman Ward. To be truthful, I didn't like it when I was there. I hated being uprooted from friends and family and stuck in an all-boys school 100 miles from home. In my case I was sent there because my dad had always wanted to go to a military school when he was growing up so he gave me the opportunity that he never had. (Thanks Dad.) I don't know to this day whether Lyman Ward helped me or not. I was not a bad kid, I didn't get in trouble and I made decent grades. But I know that it helped the vast majority of boys that I went to school with, most of whom had a choice of military school, reform school or juvenile hall.

What I know about Lyman Ward is that it's hard. It's hard being taken from everything you know and placed among strangers. I also know this. There are many young men who would not be where they are today if it were not for their parent's courage to send them to Lyman Ward. I also know young men who would not be alive today if not for the discipline of Lyman Ward.

LWMA is an extremely hard experience but most students come out of that school with a love that is hard to explain except for the pride of what they endured and accomplished and the men that they have become.

If you have a son who is struggling with his life, Lyman Ward may be the answer that you are looking for. I disagree with those who would put their son here for a semester or a year unless they only have one year left. The longer they stay, the more they will grow into young men that you can be proud of.

name: Holli Renfroe
text: I have been working at Lyman Ward now going on three years. I came to the school straight out of college. Needless to say, it took some time getting use to. When I first drove up for my interview, I immediately wanted to drive away, but something made me stay. I'm glad I did. By the end of the day, I was completely enamored with the school, the people, the landscape....all of it. There are going to be ups and downs at every school. We have and continue to work through our troubles just like an other institution. But the thing I wish more people could understand is that when students get sent to us, they don't stay students for long. They become family. Sometimes we have kids who go here from sixth grade to twelfth. Some of the kids have even been here longer than me. They feel like a part of the place, and when they leave, they take a piece of it with them. I hate to see them leave, but I am glad because I know we have done everything we can for them in order to teach the to "walk of life."

name: Dwight Michael Logan
text: Most people's bad expierences or what they at least claim from here is because they didn't want the choice of making the best of a life changing opportunity right in front of them but luckily I was one to change my ways & my life, at first I hated it because I thought I was right about everything in life & I didn't know what the school was about or what it could do for me, my parents & I didn't get along at all & I didn't have a single ounce of respect from them. After a month of being stubborn at the school I came to realization that it was time to grow up and try to see what I could do with the opportunity.. I took full advantage of it. I completed AP psychology with a 90% overall along with making the President's List (grades I had always wanted but always came up short in public school) I started the school first track & field team ( accomplished a state championship) & joined the prestigious Sword Drill team only other performed by The Citadel, my parents & I came together soon & now I have their absolute & complete respect. My 2nd year I chose to go back because I loved it, realized I needed it, & I could do so much more with my accomplishments. To put it short I was a Cadet Captain & Company Commander throughout the year, I made the President's List all 4X, I got a scholarship to Marion Military Institute (50% Tuition). The place is challenging but it's amazing what it presents, you have to want it & make the most of your potential, it changed my life & I have a band of brothers that will be friends for a lifetime, it's brought out confidence & strength that public school couldn't & all I have to say is for those who want a great challenge with great rewards come here & remember anything easy isn't worth having.

name: Nathan Shipman
text: I went to Lwma for the 2013 year and if what the guy in the review after this said was true its gone downhill. Yes we had great faculty and staff but the students were horrible. I was in 7th grade and I was constantly running from people trying to beat me up for either anger that was being taken out on me or just plain for fun. I would not suggest sending your kid here if they aren't tough and big people. But even after all that I got a really good education. My grades went way up and the teachers were really nice. Over all I give Lyman ward a 5 out of 10.

name: Mostapha M. Howaidy
text:
I'm 40 now and my experience at LWMA remains the most valued in my entire life. It simply prepared me to face the world with all it's difficulties. I'm grateful to everyone at LWMA for their efforts and dedications. Col. Bill Jennerette was an idol and a man to look up to, I miss him. My classmates are still close to each other after 22 years since graduation. We love each other and still connect no matter where we are. Thank you Lyman Ward for being part of my life.

Mostapha M. Howaidy (95')

text: Greatest school experience of my life. Would go again.

name: Brendan Curran
text:
So I attended Lyman ward when I was 15. And to be honest I was a complete jack ass and was going to die from drugs or go to prison etc. I was lazy never worked never worked out barley socialized with people and ran with a few bad kids growing up . To make a long story short it was partially my desicion to go . The first day I hated it so much you couldn't understand it was like I was beaten and locked in a room but a few squad leaders and the patlion leader told when you start your a scrub for 28 days and it was honestly horrible i was beaten l. And i kept getting in trouble and wanted to leave. After my 28 days it Sort of mad all sense it was ment to break you down see how much you can take. There was actually very fun memories there it gives you oppertunities to try new things . I played football on a team for the first time. Took tactical tranning and weight lifting. Met some friends that were very nice and still talk to till this day. I was expelled 4 days left for being a dumb ass and picking a fight with someone whom did not deserve it. I was expelled . But the point is last week I thought about it. And you don't realize it while your attending but it was one of the best things to ever happen I didn't realize till a week ago. The on istinct didn't act like a dumbass, didn't do drugs, didn't hang with the wrong people. It was just natrul it just came became a good way of life. I am now 20 years old work as a armed security officer. Starting college in a few weeks and enlisting in the military after college. So again it is a good desicion at the out come. But It is bullshit while attending.  Thank you Beverley, Erickson, King, kernel, and the goodman
Brendan CURRAN from Boston

text: It’s a complete waste of time dealing with some of the teachers at this school. You can try to reason with them until you’re blue in the face and it will all be for nothing. What happened to detention based on behavioral issues???  Also they can’t speak with you and you alone regarding whatever issue they have. they have to discuss the child amongst the other teachers and then all group up like a zombie horde to deal with you. I sat in on some of their classes and was immediately disappointed. One teacher in particular was extremely disrespectful to the students. She yelled at the students the entire class. Her behavior was extremely erratic, and she’s just downright rude. Keep in mind this is while a parent was sitting in on her class. Imagine how she behaves on a normal day. Some of the staff need to figure out why they chose the field they’re in. Are you a motivator? Are you a leader? Do you love molding minds? Do you believe that every child is worth fighting for? name: Frances Hite
text: It Gets Better Everyday! I was a parent that was determined for many many years that my child would NEVER go to this school.  But with the EXCELLENT work of Dr. Brenda Coley and the newly appointed Principle Ms. Johnston, I have completely changed my view and attitude of this school.  The days of rudeness, not caring, and students doing what they want when they want are gone!!! Ms. Johnston holds her staff and the students to ALL Russell County School District rules and regulations.  If even on student from RCSM is at a sporting activity, extra curricular activity and student support program she is there.  Her leading by example as the teachers and faculty doing the same.  The student body and facility work as a team. I have witnessed first hand the excitement and pride this family of adults and children show for their school, teams and themselves.  Don't believe me.......attend a pep rally, awards recognition program or just come by (unannounced) and stand in the corner and watch.  I promise you will be amazed.  Dr. Coley is known for putting the right people, in the right job and she made a bulls eye with Ms. Johnston.  I'm not saying everything is perfect.  The school didn't get broke over night and Dr. Coley and Ms. Johnston are not going to be able to fix it over night, but if you had told me in May I would be this happy with this program, I would have laughed in your face.  My child and her friends LOVE their teachers, the staff and each other.  Ms. Johnston practices that respect is given to EVERYONE regardless of age, gender or race.  She gives it and she expects it to be given from her staff, faculty and student body.  The teachers want these students to do well.  It's no long "collecting" a pay check for them.  Those attitudes and personnel are gone.  Before you judge/write/say anything negative about this school based on actions, information, attitudes prior to Dr. Coley and Ms. Johnston taking charge, come by the school, talk to the staff, students,  volunteer, attended an after school activity, you too will love this place.  But, I must say that it is not all Russell County Middle School or the Superintendents job to make this better.  As a VERY active parent, I have learned that unless you get involved in your child's academic life, friends, and activities that the school and district can only go so far.  The policy now is the front and back door are always open.  Come and see for yourself.  Make an appointment, can't come in person......call your child's teacher.  I promise you....you'll LOVE the results.

name: Ragan White
text: I am a first time parent, and it can be an anxious experience to start your child in daycare. I recently enrolled my son here under the new ownership of Big Blue Marble and I could not be happier with this facility! He is being engaged every day, and when I get him home he is so much more animated and talkative (as much as one can be for 4 months old). The staff takes great covid precautions with pickup, dropoffs and the rooms, and they always make it a really fun experience for him and for me every day. I think any time you take your kid to day care you need to expect that they are going to be exposed to more germs and be sick a little more, but that's going to happen whether it be day care, preschool, kindergarten, church or sports. It's unavoidable if you want your child to interact with the world outside of your home. If you are looking for a learning center / day care that offers real engagement, wonderful teachers and staff, and parent peace of mind - I highly recommend Big Blue Marble on e Glenn!

I’d suggest looking elsewhere or you’ll end up paying for daycare and taking sick days from work to take care of your child.

name: Shashank Rao
text:
We have tried Milestones on two separate occasions - first when our son was an infant (8 weeks to 4 months old) and now when he turned 18 months old.  Both times the experience was HORRIBLE (not sure why we even decided to give them a second chance after the first time's issues). As an infant, he was sick every alternate week while at Milestones.  One week he would go to Milestones and catch something, then we would keep him home for a week and fix him up.  The next week he would catch something else again.  It was a perpetual cycle because of which we decided to pull him out.

He then restarted daycare (somewhere else) when he was a year old.  For 6 months he was relatively healthy - barring the occasional cough / cold.  We started him back at Milestones this week (i.e. 18  months).  He has been there all of 3 days and already he has caught a stomach bug. This place is horrible!  On day 1 when we went to pick him up, his milk cup was not washed and just sitting around.  The second day, his pacifier was missing.  When I asked the teacher where his pacifier was, she started looking among the toys.  That should have been my first clue - if the teacher is looking for a pacifier amongst the toys, god alone knows how many kids have put it in their mouth!  And the pacifier had a string attached to it, so they could just have clipped it to our son, but they did not care to do that.  The "teachers" as such are a bunch of college kids, and most of them have no clue what they are doing.  As such, it is a revolving door for teachers; there is so much turnover that almost anyone you speak with says they are new.  If you care for your child's health, please stay away from this place!

name: Abby Wang
text: Their facility is very new, so it looks good if you take a tour as a first time visitor. My child kept getting sick during his stay, and I had to withdraw him from the center after I found him another place. They use plugin air fresheners with VERY STRONG scent, even an adult would feel very uncomfortable while staying in the room. I was really worried that my son's health might be hazarded by those chemical stuff. Are those things allowed to be used in a childcare center by regulation? Also, their playground is paved with pebbles, which is ridiculous and rather unsafe for outdoor activities!

text:
I am a 7th grader in this school and I love this school. I'm in NASA's Best which is a class for advanced learners. I'm proud to be a part of it. There aren't as many fights as there used to be. The students are defiant, and misbehave constantly, but that isn't the teacher's fault. There is one security guard and one police officer. Talking in the hallway is not allowed, yet people still do it. That's why they get extra homework and detention. Maybe if people acted right they wouldn't be getting in trouble.

EDIT: Lmao I hate this school. NASA's Best was great but now we just do computer work. There still aren't too many fights, which is boring. Kids are still defiant, and I understand why. I don't know what was wrong with me last year. Mrs. Farmer is ok, but if she expects us to come to her when we have an issue that's really funny. Some of these teachers get into personal business that isn't their own, some don't put in grades, and some just flat out bore me. Mrs. Henderson (the art teacher) and Mr. King (the choir teacher) are pretty much the best things about this school. Lunch ladies don't let me get seconds, but at the end of the day they still throw out food, which is wasteful. The food itself is a little better, which is funny because it only got better my last year. Everyday I walk these halls and I die a little inside. This school hasn't prepared me for anything but failure. Can't wait for the day I get to walk out of here for the last time and never come back. One star.

name: CMDR Catboy
text:
Get a concussion at this school and all the kid gets is a day of In School Suspension. Ive been bullied relentlessly and it felt like all they got was a pat on the wrist.
If you have a problem you are going to have to talk to the student directly which does more harm then good considering the mindset of the students here.
Several teachers are downright hostile and horrible teachers, singling out students just because they are different.
Im going to Gadsden City this year, after 4 years of this school i can comfortably say im not going to miss anyone at this school because of how rude, hostile, and utterly ignorant the students here are.
